page.title: 04"BEDGEBURY"
page.content: First mentioned in an A.D. 814 deed, Bedgebury Manor was owned by several de Bedgebury and Colepeper generations living in the original house where the Great Lake is now. In 1862-8 Hayes built the present manor in red brick, a later dam forming the Great Lake. Lord Beresford bought Bedgebury in 1836, encasing the house with local sandstone. He married Louisa Hope; the name Beresford-Hope is linked with many 19C developments in the Kilndown and Bedgebury areas. The estate was eventually split between Crown (later Forestry Commission) and School. The house basement contains services e.g. laundry; ground floor has library and diningrooms; sanatorium and staff rooms are on the first floor; above are dormitories. Former stables and lofts are now studios, laboratories, classrooms, Chapel and 6th Form rooms.
